Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Day 23/100 : Wait Handling In Selenium Using ImplicitlyWaitQuestion: What is an implicit wait in Selenium WebDriver, and how does it work in test automation?Implicit waitÂ : Implicit wait is a type of wait in Selenium WebDriver that instructs the driver to wait for a certain amount of time before throwing   aÂ NoSuchElementException.  1.It applies toÂ all elementsÂ in the script and helps toÂ handle dynamic elements       that take time to load. 2.The default setting is 0 3.driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(20)) Output : 1.The browser opens https://lnkd.in/g_nNdJ_u. 2.It waits up to 10 seconds for elements to appear before interacting. 3.The "Dropdown" button is clicked. 4.The "Facebook" link is found and clicked. 5.The browser closes successfully.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#AutomationTesting hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#Selenium hashtag#Java hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#SDET ğŸ˜Š

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Java 24 .Programming language are evolving ,java is one of those languages.Oracle recently announced the release of Java 24 on 18 March 2024. In as much as the language is evolving, it will take time for the Java Community to trust Oracle with the gimmick they pulled over licencing. The java community has not really moved away from java 8 . Most enterprise systems are still using Java 8. Let's wait and see what oracle will do with language. I am still a big java fan. I will experiment with the new features especially stream gatherers and see what they have to offer. hashtag#java24

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

In as much as the language is evolving, it will take time for the Java Community to trust Oracle with the gimmick they pulled over licencing. Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Accenture Glitch: A 2- Year Struggle with No Resolution I have been facing an unbelievable registration issue with Accenture for the last two years - and despite my best efforts, there has been no response or resolution.Every time I try to register for job opportunities, I get the same notification "We already have your profile in our database" message. However, I have not been able to proceed beyond this step.To make things worse, I have raised hundreds of tickets over this period, hoping for assistance. But the response? Absolute silence. No emails, no resolutions - Just a frustrating cycle of being stuck without any support.This is not just a minor inconvenience, it's a roadblock for candidates eager to explore opportunities at Accenture. If a technical glitch has been persisting for so long without being addressed, how many other candidates are facing the same issue in silence?I am sharing this publicly in the hope that someone from Accenture's HR, Technical or support team takes notice and finally resolves this issue.If anyone in my network has experienced this, or if you know someone at Accenture who can help, please like, comment, or share this post in your network to bring attention to this ongoing problem.It's time to get this fixed.hashtag#Accenture hashtag#HiringIssues hashtag#RecruitmentGlitch hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Technicisse hashtag#CareerRoadblock hashtag#AccentureIndia

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸš€

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Day 23/100 : Wait Handling In Selenium Using ImplicitlyWaitQuestion: What is an implicit wait in Selenium WebDriver, and how does it work in test automation?Implicit waitÂ : Implicit wait is a type of wait in Selenium WebDriver that instructs the driver to wait for a certain amount of time before throwing   aÂ NoSuchElementException.  1.It applies toÂ all elementsÂ in the script and helps toÂ handle dynamic elements       that take time to load. 2.The default setting is 0 3.driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(20)) Output : 1.The browser opens https://lnkd.in/g_nNdJ_u. 2.It waits up to 10 seconds for elements to appear before interacting. 3.The "Dropdown" button is clicked. 4.The "Facebook" link is found and clicked. 5.The browser closes successfully.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#AutomationTesting hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#Selenium hashtag#Java hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#SDET ğŸ˜Š

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸš€

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

In as much as the language is evolving, it will take time for the Java Community to trust Oracle with the gimmick they pulled over licencing. The java community has not really moved away from java 8 . Most enterprise systems are still using Java 8. Let's wait and see what oracle will do with language. I am still a big java fan. I will experiment with the new features especially stream gatherers and see what they have to offer. hashtag#java24

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸš€

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Day 23/100 : Wait Handling In Selenium Using ImplicitlyWaitQuestion: What is an implicit wait in Selenium WebDriver, and how does it work in test automation?Implicit waitÂ : Implicit wait is a type of wait in Selenium WebDriver that instructs the driver to wait for a certain amount of time before throwing   aÂ NoSuchElementException.  1.It applies toÂ all elementsÂ in the script and helps toÂ handle dynamic elements       that take time to load. 2.The default setting is 0 3.driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(20)) Output : 1.The browser opens https://lnkd.in/g_nNdJ_u. 2.It waits up to 10 seconds for elements to appear before interacting. 3.The "Dropdown" button is clicked. 4.The "Facebook" link is found and clicked. 5.The browser closes successfully.hashtag#Hiring hashtag#OpenToWork hashtag#Recruitment hashtag#HR hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#AutomationTesting hashtag#QAEngineer hashtag#Selenium hashtag#Java hashtag#TestAutomation hashtag#QualityAssurance hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#SDET ğŸ˜Š

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Letâ€™s discuss! ğŸš€

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Chefs secretThere is gold in inbound candidates.Only one catch.They need to apply.With Doghouse weâ€™ve filled more than 30% of our roles last year with inbound candidates. Nowadays our brand and following definitely plays a part, but weâ€™ve always attracted strong candidates with our vacancies, even when we just started out in 2015.3 crucial factors in your vacancies when hiring for technology, where I see a lot of companies still make mistakes:#1 searchableKey words for technologies are essential to show up in peopleâ€™s searches. I still see roles for developer or cloud architect without specific tech stack mentioned ğŸ¤·ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸Java developers will search for â€œsoftware developer Javaâ€, so they simply donâ€™t find your vacancy if you donâ€™t mention Java in it.Sound simple but I still see those vacancies.Even if you look for an agnost, or donâ€™t care which tech they worked with (for instance with cloud), at least name the main vendor technologies to show up in searches (AWS, GCP, Azure).#2 write about the techToo many vacancies spend the majority of the vacancies on the company, culture and broad work descriptions. The tech people want to know about the bits and bites. Share some ongoing projects or innovations you try to apply. The more technical the better in my experience. Ask the technical lead for some serious input.#3 know where to postSome companies still mainly leverage their website. Whilst this works for the likes of Adyen and Miro, many smaller company websites donâ€™t get much traffic. Post in job boards or LinkedIn instead. We get strongest quality of applicants as well as most volume still from LinkedIn.If you are not already applying this to you vacancies for hires on technology, start today! ğŸ«µğŸ»Small changes can lead to big results, all you need is that one killer candidate to apply ğŸ’ªğŸ»

Ever wondered why Go (Golang) is so efficient at handling concurrency?It's not just goroutinesâ€”the real magic lies in Goâ€™s work-stealing scheduler.Unlike traditional thread-based concurrency models, Go's scheduler is smartâ€”it dynamically steals work from idle processors, ensuring maximum CPU utilization and blazing-fast execution.How Go Handles Concurrency?Go doesnâ€™t rely on OS threads the way traditional languages do. Instead, it introduces:- Goroutines â€“ Lightweight, managed by Go, not the OS.- GOMAXPROCS â€“ Controls the number of OS threads used.- M:N Scheduling â€“ Maps thousands of goroutines to a limited number of OS threads.Unlike Python or Java, Goâ€™s runtime handles scheduling instead of leaving it to the OS.This is where the work-stealing algorithm shines.- How Work Stealing WorksInstead of a single queue for all tasks (which can create bottlenecks), Goâ€™s scheduler assigns each thread (P) its own local queue.Magic happens when one thread runs out of work.- If a threadâ€™s queue is empty, it doesnâ€™t sit idle.- Instead, it steals tasks from another threadâ€™s queue.- This keeps the system balanced and efficient.No thread is left waiting when there's work to be done.Goâ€™s work-stealing approach provides:- Lower Latency â€“ Tasks get scheduled faster without bottlenecks.- Better CPU Utilization â€“ No cores sit idle while others are overloaded.- Scalability â€“ Thousands (or millions) of goroutines run smoothly.For comparison: - Thread pools (like in Java) often create contention due to global queues. - Manual concurrency (like in C++) requires explicit thread management.Go automates all of this, making concurrency simple yet powerful.If youâ€™re building high-performance, concurrent applications:- Use goroutines freely â€“ The scheduler will optimize execution.- Avoid blocking calls â€“ Blocking a goroutine blocks the underlying OS thread.- Tune GOMAXPROCS â€“ Default is based on CPU cores but can be tweaked.Goâ€™s smart scheduler + work-stealing means you get parallel performance without managing threads manually.Goâ€™s concurrency model isnâ€™t just about goroutines.Itâ€™s about how Go efficiently balances work across cores, ensuring no CPU cycle is wasted.- A smarter scheduler means better performance.- Work stealing ensures fairness and responsiveness.- You write simple code, and Go handles the complexity.Thatâ€™s why Go is one of the best languages for scalable applications.hashtag#golang hashtag#scaling hashtag#developers hashtag#coding hashtag#vibecoding hashtag#ai hashtag#ml hashtag#Jhibli hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#mean hashtag#mern hashtag#go

Java 24 .Programming language are evolving ,java is one of those languages.Oracle recently announced the release of Java 24 on 18 March 2024. In as much as the language is evolving, it will take time for the Java Community to trust Oracle with the gimmick they pulled over licencing. The java community has not really moved away from java 8 . Most enterprise systems are still using Java 8. Let's wait and see what oracle will do with language. I am still a big java fan. I will experiment with the new features especially stream gatherers and see what they have to offer. hashtag#java24

Abstract Class vs Interface in JavaWhen designing object-oriented systems in Java, choosing between abstract classes and interfaces is crucial. Both prevent direct instantiation, but they serve different purposes.Key Differencesâœ… Abstract Class:Can have both abstract and concrete methods.Allows instance variables.A class can extend only one abstract class.Used when classes share common state/behavior.âœ… Interface:Contains only abstract methods (before Java 8).Can only have static and final variables.A class can implement multiple interfaces.Used when classes share only behavior (method signatures).When to Use What?ğŸ”¹ Use abstract classes when you need shared behavior and state.ğŸ”¹ Use interfaces when you need a contract that multiple classes must follow.For example, in a Vehicle system:An abstract class can define shared properties like speed and fuelType.An interface like Drivable ensures all vehicles implement accelerate() and brake().Whatâ€™s your approach when designing Java applications? Chefs secretThere is gold in inbound candidates.Only one catch.They need to apply.With Doghouse weâ€™ve filled more than 30% of our roles last year with inbound candidates. Nowadays our brand and following definitely plays a part, but weâ€™ve always attracted strong candidates with our vacancies, even when we just started out in 2015.3 crucial factors in your vacancies when hiring for technology, where I see a lot of companies still make mistakes:#1 searchableKey words for technologies are essential to show up in peopleâ€™s searches. I still see roles for developer or cloud architect without specific tech stack mentioned ğŸ¤·ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸Java developers will search for â€œsoftware developer Javaâ€, so they simply donâ€™t find your vacancy if you donâ€™t mention Java in it.Sound simple but I still see those vacancies.Even if you look for an agnost, or donâ€™t care which tech they worked with (for instance with cloud), at least name the main vendor technologies to show up in searches (AWS, GCP, Azure).#2 write about the techToo many vacancies spend the majority of the vacancies on the company, culture and broad work descriptions. The tech people want to know about the bits and bites. Share some ongoing projects or innovations you try to apply. The more technical the better in my experience. Ask the technical lead for some serious input.#3 know where to postSome companies still mainly leverage their website. Whilst this works for the likes of Adyen and Miro, many smaller company websites donâ€™t get much traffic. Post in job boards or LinkedIn instead. We get strongest quality of applicants as well as most volume still from LinkedIn.If you are not already applying this to you vacancies for hires on technology, start today! ğŸ«µğŸ»Small changes can lead to big results, all you need is that one killer candidate to apply ğŸ’ªğŸ»
